Emergency Response Program Information 

Big West Oil maintains an Emergency Response Action Plan and a Facility Response Plan that describe actions to take in an emergency. Our emergency response program is based upon OSHA PSM and RMP guidelines. The refinery maintains an inventory of spill response and fire-fighting equipment on site, and the facility maintains hazardous materials and fire brigade crews which train twice a month. The refinery participates in the Petroleum Mutual Aid Program in which area refineries would assist each other in the event of an emergency. A fully equipped HAZMAT vehicle and three fire trucks are also maintained on site for use by the emergency response teams. Additional mitigation measures are also in place to reduce any release that may occur. Big West Oil has also coordinated its emergency response program with the Davis County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire department and any potentially affected neighbors. 

 
Five-year Incident History 

Big West oil has not had any incidents in the last five years that fall within the RMP criteria significant accidental releases of one or more of the regulated substances from a covered process in the five years prior to the submission of an initial or updated Risk Management Plan. 


Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

Big West Oil continues in its program to upgrade our fire water system, add additional firefighting equipment and install fence line and process unit perimeter monitoring systems. Big West Oils safety department has recently been making significant strides to improve occupational and process safety. Big West Oil was awarded the Step Change in Safety award by the Utah Petroleum Association, highlighting the refinerys process pertaining to process and refinery safety. lysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. For higher severity incidents that have a worst-case potential of a fatality, a Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) is conducted to quantify the amount of risk reduction provided by the safeguards identified during the HAZOP. The analyses are conducted using a team of personnel with operations, maintenance, and engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process and accident prevention and mitigation measures. Recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures are provided by the team when deemed necessary.

Refinery operations are conducted according to standard operating procedures described in unit-specific training manuals and employees are trained in unit-specific operating procedures. Big West Oil ensures mechanical integrity of its processes by utilizing methods to verify materials of construction of process piping and equipment, performing regular testing of piping and equipment, and by conducting routine inspections and promptly correcting identified deficiencies. Changes made to refinery processes are professionally managed through Big West Oils management of change (MOC) process, both notifying and training applicable personnel of the change. 


Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 

Big West Oils chemical-specific release prevention systems include temperature, pressure, and flow alarms, and automatic shutdown systems for process parameters such as high level and high temperature. Process vessels, tanks, and piping are equipped with pressure relief systems that route materials to knock-out drums and flares.  

In addition to the release prevention program activities, the Refinery has safety features on many units to detect a release, help contain/control a release, and reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. Big West Oil operates release detection, release containment and control equipment and release mitiga

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

Big West Oil, LLC  North Salt Lake Refinery (Big West Oil) has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training programs, equipment inspection programs, operating procedures, and engineering and administrative controls in our process. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable State and Federal rules and regulations. Our main goal is to take steps necessary to prevent releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, we have trained personnel and the appropriate equipment to respond to the release and implement control and containment strategies. 


Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

Big West Oils North Salt Lake Refinery produces primary products from raw crude oil. These products include gasoline, diesel fuel, fuel oil, propane, butane and isobutane produced from raw crude oil. The refinery has several regulated flammable substances such as butane, isobutane, pentane, propane, propylene and hydrofluoric acid (anhydrous) which is a regulated toxic substance. 


General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps 

Processes at the refinery regulated by the Risk Management Plan (RMP) are also regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 1910.119. Big West Oils PSM program includes detailed process safety information for each process to manage compliance with the requirements of each element of the PSM and RMP regulations. These programs aim to prevent or mitigate the accidental release of hazardous substances from equipment with the potential of affecting workers and nearby receptors.
